title: Poster Spotlights

author: Alastair Moore, Department of Computer Science, University College London

Egil Bae, University of Bergen

segmentation: Hi, I'm Alistair and this is work done at University College London with my supervisor Simon.
Press and collaborator Jonathan World many vision algorithms use super pixels for inference for two principal reasons.
First, greater efficiency and second because they provide compact regions of support for feature vectors.
In this work, we submit an image into a regular grid of super pixels, which we call a superpixel lattice.

The motivation for this is to maintain some of the useful properties of pixels, like the fact they can be stored in arrays, but more importantly to allow vision algorithms to use a representation where the underlying graph has a fixed topology so that, for instance, we subsequently when we're learning clique potentials, we can do so between regions that have fixed orientation and fixed neighborhood relations.
In this work, we show that we can construct a globally optimal solution in either horizontal or vertical direction, where we start with a regular grid.

But you can see an example A and then alternate between improving the vertical and horizontal boundaries to produce a final lattice, which you can see in D. At each step we obtain a solution with a single St cut using a novel graph construction.

This graph forces the label field to conform to a set of ordered layers, as illustrated on the bottom, and we have some nice results when compared to competing methods and hope that Additionally the graph may prove useful for some segmenting objects with ordered parts.
Thank you.
